title: Six people freed after years of 'waiting for the world to end'
text:
Police are investigating after discovering a 58-year-old man and six of his adult children inside the house (Picture: PA/Rex)

A man kept his six adult children in the cellar of a remote farm for years ‘waiting for the end of time’.

The children were only discovered when his eldest son – now a man – stumbled into a nearby cafe in the town of Ruinerwold, in Drenthe, Netherlands.

He told the owner he had not been outside for nine years.

Police then found a man, 58, had been keeping his six suspected adult children – aged 16 to 25 – in the isolated farmhouse without anyone knowing they existed.

The oldest son is understood to have entered the cafe several times but the last time he entered, on Sunday, he told the owner he wanted to ‘end’ the way he and his siblings were living.

Some of the children have never had any contact with neighbours and were convinced they were the only humans on earth, according to local media.

The farm where the man and six suspected children had been living in the Netherlands (Picture: Rex)

Police in Drenthe found a man and his six adult children living in the cellar of the isolated farmhouse (Picture: PA)

The farmhouse is in Drenthe, in Ruinerwold, Netherlands

A cafe owner said he called the police after one of the people kept in the basement told him he hadn’t been outside in nine years (Picture: Alamy)

Cafe owner Chris Westerbeek told Dutch broadcaster RTV Drenthe: ‘He was very confused.

‘He ordered five beers and drank them. Then I had a chat with him and he told me he had run away and needed help.

‘Then we called the police.’

The man was described as having long hair and a beard and claimed to have not been outside for almost a decade.

Chris said: ‘He said he had brothers and sisters who lived in the farm.

‘He said he was the oldest and wanted to end the way they were living.’

Police went to the farmhouse and found a secret flight of stairs in the sitting room hidden behind a cupboard which led to the family’s hiding place.

Those staying on the farm sustained themselves on vegetables grown in the garden and goats kept in a plot outside (Picture: Rex)

The landlord of the farm said he ‘knew nothing’ of the people living inside the building (Picture: Rex)

The older man – believed to be the siblings’ father – was in bed, having had a stroke several years ago, police said.

It is not known how long the family had been living in the cellar or what happened to the children’s mother.

The children had no contact with the outside world and lived completely self-sufficiently with their own vegetable garden and a goat.

A neighbour of the farm told RTV Drenthe he thought the man, who had boarded up all the farm windows, lived there alone.

He told local reporters: ‘I am shaking on my legs.’

Police confirmed finding the family and opened an investigation last night which they said is ongoing.

The town of Ruinerwold has a population of just under 4,000 people

The relationship between the seven people found has not been confirmed but officers said the 58-year-old has been arrested.

The area around the farm is closed.

A police spokesperson said: ‘First and foremost, we see it as our task to offer good care and support to the family.’

According to people living nearby the farm has been surrounded by high fences for several years.

It is owned by a man who lives in the town, who believed he was renting to a single man and said he ‘knew nothing’ of the tenant or any children.

The town of Ruinerwold has a population of just under 4,000 people.

description: The oldest of six adult children stumbled into a cafe this weekend and told the owner he had not been outside for years.
